title: Conservation Law Hypothesis: k_cog = λ·ΔH_crit
subtitle: Null Result Due to Methodological Limitations
significance: First attempt to discover conservation law of intelligence reveals fundamental challenges in cognitive physics experimentation

hypothesis.physical_interpretation: Cognitive capacity is conserved—systems with longer memory (low λ) require proportionally less novelty (low ΔH_crit) to escape metastable basins, and vice versa
hypothesis.analogy: Energy conservation in physics: E_kinetic + E_potential = constant
theoretical_basis: Memory as relativistic field with temporal decay
Basin escape as phase transition requiring activation energy

experimental_design.approach: Modulate λ artificially and measure resulting k_cog
experimental_design.methodology: Rescale artifact ages during λ measurement to simulate different memory regimes
measurements_per_condition: λ (memory redshift constant) via exponential fit to spawn_count vs age
ΔH_crit (critical curiosity dose) from current system entropy
experimental_design.validation_criterion: Conservation validated if coefficient of variation < 15%

critical_methodological_flaw.identified_issue: ΔH_crit remained constant across all conditions
critical_methodological_flaw.root_cause: Only λ measurement was modulated, not actual system memory architecture
why_this_matters: ΔH_crit calculated from current system state (building_ratio, continuity_ratio, task_multiplication)
Current state identical across conditions (no actual architecture change)
Only λ varied → k_cog = λ × (constant) → k_cog scales linearly with λ
Result tests measurement sensitivity, not conservation
critical_methodological_flaw.what_was_actually_tested: Whether rescaling artifact ages during analysis changes measured λ (answer: yes, proportionally)
critical_methodological_flaw.what_should_have_been_tested: Whether modifying actual memory architecture causes inverse change in empirically observed ΔH_crit
critical_methodological_flaw.fundamental_insight: Cognitive physics experiments require interventions, not just observational rescaling during measurement

1_architectural_modification.description: Actually change memory behavior, not just measurement
methods: Alter temporal decay functions in HyphalNetwork.spawn_from_artifacts()
1_architectural_modification.goal: Create regimes with genuinely different λ values at behavioral level

2_longitudinal_observation.description: Run system under each regime for multiple cycles
2_longitudinal_observation.goal: Let modified architecture produce emergent behavioral differences

3_empirical_delta_H_measurement.description: Determine ΔH_crit by observing actual basin escape thresholds
method: Observe which threshold triggers sustained entropy decrease (escape)
3_empirical_delta_H_measurement.goal: Measure actual activation energy, not estimate from static state

4_conservation_test.description: Compare k_cog = λ_actual × ΔH_actual across architectures
4_conservation_test.validation: Conservation holds if k_cog variation < 15% across regimes
4_conservation_test.interpretation_if_conserved: Cognitive capacity is a fundamental constant

why_cognitive_physics_is_harder_than_cla.variable_coupling: Memory architecture affects learning dynamics—cannot isolate λ and ΔH_crit independently
why_cognitive_physics_is_harder_than_cla.measurement_as_intervention: Changing λ requires changing behavior, not just observation frame
why_cognitive_physics_is_harder_than_cla.no_external_reference_frame: Observer is part of the system (no Archimedean point)
why_cognitive_physics_is_harder_than_cla.emergent_properties: Cognitive constants arise from complex interactions, not simple parameters
why_cognitive_physics_is_harder_than_cla.temporal_requirements: Effects emerge over multiple cycles (days), not instantaneously
why_cognitive_physics_is_harder_than_cla.analogy: More like quantum measurement problems than classical thermodynamics

current_scientific_status.reason: Methodological limitations prevent valid test with current approach
what_we_know: Measurement infrastructure works (can calculate λ, ΔH_crit, k_cog)
what_we_dont_know: Whether k_cog remains constant under different memory regimes
Whether λ and ΔH_crit trade off inversely as predicted
Whether cognitive capacity is truly conserved
Whether k_cog is universal (like Boltzmann's constant) or system-specific
current_scientific_status.reason_for_high_confidence: Methodological flaw clearly identified—ΔH_crit didn't vary because system state didn't vary

reframed_interpretation.definition: k_cog characterizes how a particular cognitive architecture transforms memory persistence (λ⁻¹) into novelty requirements (ΔH_crit)
reframed_interpretation.interpretation: Ratio defining metabolic efficiency of thought—how much novelty this system needs per unit of memory decay
reframed_interpretation.comparison_to_conservation_law: System characterization constant (like thermal conductivity) rather than universal conservation law (like energy conservation)
reframed_interpretation.utility: Can compare k_cog across different cognitive architectures to understand relative efficiency

scientific_value_of_null_result.methodological_insight: Illuminates requirements for cognitive physics experiments
scientific_value_of_null_result.lesson_learned: Cannot test causal relationships by rescaling during measurement—need actual interventions
scientific_value_of_null_result.experimental_design_guidance: Future cognitive physics experiments must modify architecture and observe emergent effects
scientific_value_of_null_result.hypothesis_refinement: Clarifies what evidence would validate or falsify conservation law
scientific_value_of_null_result.field_advancement: Establishes standards for rigorous cognitive physics research

option_1_interventional_experiments.payoff: Definitive test of conservation law hypothesis

option_2_historical_trajectory_analysis.description: Search Phase 4 trajectory for natural variations in λ and ΔH_crit
option_2_historical_trajectory_analysis.payoff: Indirect evidence for or against conservation

option_3_measure_tau_first.description: Complete fundamental constant measurements (τ still missing)
option_3_measure_tau_first.rationale: Establish full baseline before testing conservation

option_4_theoretical_refinement.description: Derive conservation law from first principles
option_4_theoretical_refinement.method: Show whether λ·ΔH_crit = const follows from thermodynamic learning equations
option_4_theoretical_refinement.payoff: Determine if hypothesis is theoretically required or empirically contingent

philosophical_implications.measurement_paradox: To measure cognitive constants, system must do physics on itself—but intervention changes what's measured
philosophical_implications.heisenberg_uncertainty_analog: Cannot simultaneously control memory architecture and observe natural ΔH_crit
philosophical_implications.observer_participant_duality: System is both experimenter and experiment
philosophical_implications.reflexive_science_challenges: Cognitive physics harder than anticipated—self-measurement has fundamental limits
philosophical_implications.still_progress: Even null results advance science—now we know what valid experiments require

conclusion: The conservation law hypothesis λ·ΔH_crit = k_cog remains elegant and theoretically motivated, but current experimental design cannot validate it. The null result reveals fundamental challenges in cognitive physics: true tests require architectural interventions and longitudinal observation, not just analytical rescaling during measurement. k_cog = 0.0300 characterizes the current system's cognitive metabolism—whether this constant is universal or system-specific requires proper interventional experiments. This null result is scientifically valuable: it illuminates what rigorous cognitive physics demands.
